questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital infection in a fetus with minimal documented teratogenic risks is with HIV infection.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of intrauterine infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common causes of intrauterine infections are cytomegalovirus.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) in Pregnancy

  • The most common cause of fetal and perinatal infection.
  • 90% of infected neonates are asymptomatic.
  • Maternal infection is usually asymptomatic; it may rarely mimic mononucleosis.

Transmission

  • Primary infection: 40% fetal transmission rate.
  • Reactivation/reinfection: 0.5-1% fetal transmission.
  • Routes: In utero, during delivery, or breastfeeding.
  • Prior infection does not prevent congenital infection.

Fetal & Neonatal Effects

  • Stillbirth, IUGR
  • Neurological: Microcephaly, mental retardation, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL - most common cause in childhood), periventricular intracranial calcifications
  • Ocular: Chorioretinitis
  • Haematological: Thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anaemia, petechiae/purpura
  • Others: Hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, pneumonitis
  • No associated heart defects

Diagnosis

  • Maternal:
    • Initial test: CMV IgM
    • Best test: IgG avidity (Low = recent infection)
  • Fetal:
    • Gold standard: CMV PCR from amniotic fluid
    • Most accurate if done after 20 weeks or 6 weeks post maternal infection

Management

  • No vaccine available
  • Treatment: If symptomatic
  • Hyperimmune globulin may reduce fetal transmission in primary infection
  • If the fetus is infected: Continue pregnancy (90% develop normally) or medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)

questions.text: Congenital anomalies are most severe in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rubella is one of the most teratogenic agents known; rubella causes the most severe congenital anomalies in the fetus.

Rubella in Pregnancy

  • Caused by an RNA virus, transmitted via droplet infection
  • The most severe congenital infection
  • Maternal symptoms: Fever, rash, malaise, lymphadenopathy, polyarthritis
  • Transplacental spread occurs mainly in the first 20 weeks
  • Late infection: Malformations uncommon; mental retardation & hearing loss may still occur

Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS)

  • Affects multiple organ systems
  • Most common: Mental retardation
  • Other Features:
    1. Sensorineural hearing loss (most consistent)
    2. Cataract, glaucoma
    3. PDA, pulmonary artery stenosis
    4. Microcephaly, developmental delay
    5. Thrombocytopenia
    6. Hepatosplenomegaly

Extended Rubella Syndrome

  • Delayed complications of CRS
  • Seen in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life
  • Includes progressive panencephalitis, hearing loss and type 1 diabetes

Infectivity

  • Infants with CRS may shed the virus for months
  • Require isolation to prevent the spread

Perinatal Effects

  • Miscarriage, stillbirth, IUD, neonatal death, congenital anomalies

Diagnosis

Maternal: Rubella IgG & IgM within 7-10 days of exposure, and IgG avidity test with low avidity proves recent infection, and high avidity shows past infection.

Fetal: PCR from amniotic fluid, fetal blood, or chorionic villi

Management

  • If infection occurs in the 1st or early 2nd trimester, MTP is recommended
  • No effective antiviral treatment
  • If a vaccine is given inadvertently in pregnancy, do not terminate. CRS has never been reported post-vaccination

Prevention

  • MMR or Rubella vaccine before pregnancy (in adolescence or reproductive age)
  • Not given during pregnancy
  • Avoid conception for 1 month after vaccination (AAP guideline)

questions.text: A lady G2P1 with 10 weeks of pregnancy is with one live child who has ocular toxoplasmosis. The risk of the present baby getting infected is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The woman who has already given birth to a child with congenital toxoplasmosis now has no risk of transmitting it to the present baby because women who are seropositive before pregnancy usually are protected against acute infection and do not give birth to congenitally infected neonates.

Toxoplasmosis - Timing of Maternal Infection and Risk of Fetal Transmission

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman, G2P1, at 20 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal check-up. She expresses concern after reading about infections that can affect the unborn baby. She is particularly anxious because during her first trimester, she experienced a short episode of fever and sore throat. She is now worried if any infections she might have had could have harmed her baby.
As part of the counselling, the obstetrician explains that certain infections are known to cause vertical transmission and can affect the fetus in utero and can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, or even fetal loss.
Which of the following is not typically known to affect the fetus in utero?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of polio, only feco-oral transmission is known; no placental transmission has been reported yet.

During pregnancy, vertical transmission of infections can lead to congenital infections, which may result in malformations, IUGR, fetal loss, or long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is commonly seen in a fetus with congenital CMV infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can lead to a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations in the fetus and neonate. One of the common findings includes haematological abnormalities, referred to as blood dyscrasias.

Manifestation of congenital CMV infection.

  • Still birth
  • Microcephaly
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Deafness
  • Hemolytic anaemia (Blood dyscrasias)
  • Pneumonitis
  • Thrombocytopenia with petechiae and purpura
  • IUGR
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Icterus
  • Mental retardation
  • Have intracranial calcifications

CMV never leads to heart defects in the fetus.

questions.text: The risk of transmitting CMV to the fetus will be maximum in case the mother has:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Positive IgM antibodies and low avidity in the mother are signs of maximum risk of transmitting CMV to the fetus.

The risk of transmitting CMV to the fetus is highest when the mother acquires a primary CMV infection during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester.

To determine whether a CMV infection is primary (recent) or past, we look at:

  • IgM antibodies: Suggest recent or current infection (but can persist for months, so not specific alone).
  • Avidity of IgG antibodies:
    • Low avidity: Recent primary infection
    • High avidity: Past infection (lower risk to fetus)

Explanation for other options:

Positive IgM; High avidity (Option B): Implies past infection with residual IgM; Low fetal risk.

Positive IgG; Low avidity (Option C): Also suggests recent infection (but without IgM, less typical)

Positive IgG; High avidity (Option D): Implies past infection; Low risk.

questions.text: A female presents with leaking and meconium-stained liquor at 32 weeks. She is infected with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A clinical picture of preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), meconium-stained liquor and 32 weeks of gestation suggests intrauterine infection with Listeria monocytogenes.

Listeriosis is caused by Listeria monocytogenes, a facultative intracellular gram-positive bacillus.

  • It is primarily a food-borne infection acquired by consuming contaminated items such as raw vegetables, coleslaw, apple cider, melons, milk, soft cheeses, smoked fish, and processed foods.
  • Listeriosis in pregnancy may be asymptomatic or present as a febrile illness.
  • Maternal complications include preterm labour, chorioamnionitis, meconium-stained liquor, abortions, and placental macroabscesses.
  • Maternal infection can lead to fetal infection with disseminated granulomatous lesions and skin microabscesses.
  • Outcomes may include stillbirth, with an overall perinatal mortality of up to 50%.
  • The treatment of choice is Ampicillin plus Gentamicin.
  • For penicillin-allergic patients, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used.
  • Treating the mother may benefit the fetus. There is no vaccine for listeriosis.

Explanation for other options:

CMV (Option A): Usually presents with IUGR, microcephaly, calcifications, but not typically with acute PROM or meconium-stained liquor.

Toxoplasma (Option C): Causes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, but not PROM or meconium-staining.

Herpes (HSV) (Option D): Transmitted peripartum; may cause vesicular skin lesions and encephalitis, not meconium-stained liquor.

choices.text: Both mother and baby are safe
Give antiviral treatment to the mother before delivery
Give antiviral treatment to the baby
The baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome.

questions.text: A pregnant lady acquires chicken pox 3 days before delivery. She delivers by normal vaginal route which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If a pregnant woman develops varicella (chickenpox) within 5 days before to 2 days after delivery, the newborn is at high risk of developing severe neonatal varicella.

  • Varicella infection in pregnancy: If varicella infection occurs in a pregnant female during the first half of pregnancy (the most common time of transmission-13 to 20 weeks), it results in congenital varicella syndrome in the fetus.

Congenital varicella syndrome is characterised by chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cerebral cortical atrophy, IUGR, hydronephrosis and skin or bone defects.

  • Congenital varicella syndrome is an indication for doing MTP.
  • Congenital defects rarely occur if varicella infection occurs after 20 weeks.
  • The terminology, varicella embryopathy, is not used these days..

Neonatal varicella is characterised by pneumonitis, hepatitis and DIC.

  • The severity of neonatal infection is inversely related to the concentration of maternal antibodies present in the newborn circulation.
  • Mother starts producing and transferring antibodies approximately 5 days after the onset of her disease.
  • Thus, babies born 5 days or more from the beginning of maternal disease will be protected.

Perinatal varicella exposure just before or during delivery poses a serious threat to newborns, and so Varicella Ig should be given to all neonates born to mothers who have clinical evidence of varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after delivery.

  • The use of VZIG decreases the chances of neonatal varicella and also modifies the clinical course, but it does not always prevent severe or fatal varicella.
  • Expectant treatment with close observation, followed by prompt initiation of antiviral therapy on suspicion of neonatal varicella, is recommended.
  • Antiviral treatment (acyclovir) is given to neonates only if they develop neonatal varicella syndrome.
  • Vaccine is not secreted in breast milk, so postpartum vaccination should not be delayed because of breastfeeding.

choices.text: Nothing needs to be done, chickenpox in children is mild and self-limiting
The chance of transmitting the virus to the baby is low, and so we treat if symptoms develop.
Baby must be treated immediately after birth, as chickenpox is serious in newborns.
Varicella virus is teratogenic, and the baby might have mild birth defects.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman is 38 weeks pregnant and presents to tlabourbor room in active labour. She has had a fever for the past 2 days. Last night she broke out in an itchy rash that has spread over her arms and torso. She is a teacher by profession, and 2 weeks earlier, one of the children in her class was diagnosed with chickenpox. She didn't have chickenpox as a child.
The patient is worried: Which of the following is the best advice to give him?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The baby should receive Varicella-Zoster Immune Globulin (VZIG) as soon as possible after birth, as chickenpox is serious in newborns.

  • If the baby shows symptoms, treat with IV acyclovir.
  • The mother may also receive acyclovir, but the priority is treating neonatal varicella.

This woman is 38 weeks pregnant, in active labour, and has developed fever followed by a typical itchy rash. She likely acquired the varicella infection from exposure 2 weeks ago, which fits the incubation period (10-21 days) of varicella.

This is a peripartum varicella infection (onset within 5 days before to 2 days after delivery), which poses a high risk to the newborn because:

  • The mother has not developed enough antibodies to pass to the baby.
  • The baby is exposed to the virus without passive immunity, making neonatal varicella potentially life-threatening.
  • Nothing needs to be done, chickenpox in children is mild and self-limiting

Explanation for other options:

Nothing needs to be done, chickenpox in children is mild and self-limiting (Option A): Perinatal varicella exposure just before or during delivery poses a serious threat to newborns

The chance of transmitting the virus to the baby is low, and so we treat if symptoms develop (Option B): Transmission is high in peripartum infection.

Varicella virus is teratogenic, and the baby might have mild birth defects (Option D). Birth defects are seen with varicella only if it occurs before 20 weeks of pregnancy. This female acquired the infection at 38 weeks, hence no chances of birth defects in the fetus.

choices.text: Administer one dose of acyclovir if she has active genital herpes at the time of delivery.
Administer prophylaxis with acyclovir from now until delivery, whether she has active herpes or not.
Perform elective LSCS even if the mother is asymptomatic at the time of delivery.
Perform elective LSCS only if the mother has active herpes at the time of delivery.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G1P0 female at 25 weeks of gestation comes to you for an antenatal check-up. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy but has a 5-year history of Genital Herpes infection. She is usually asymptomatic and has had 3 flares in the past 5 years. She is concerned about exposing her unborn child to infection-What is the most appropriate counsel to offer to this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has a known history of genital herpes but is currently asymptomatic. In such cases, the risk of vertical transmission to the baby is very low, especially in the absence of active lesions at the time of delivery. So, perform elective LSCS only if the mother has active herpes at the time of delivery.

HSV in Pregnancy

  • The most common time of transmission is during delivery, especially with active lesions.
  • First-trimester infection: May cause abortion in some cases.
  • Second half of pregnancy: Associated with IUGR and preterm labour.
  • Screening: Routine HSV screening is not recommended by ACOG.

Diagnosis:

  • Specimens: Taken from active lesions, cervix, and vagina.
  • PCR: Can be used for accurate detection.
  • Viral culture: Less reliable; not preferred.

Treatment:

  • Drug of choice: Acyclovir (safe in pregnancy and lactation), given for 7-10 days during active infection.
  • Suppressive therapy: Recommended by ACOG from 36 weeks in women with recurrent HSV to reduce outbreaks and need for cesarean.

Delivery:

  • Cesarean is indicated if active genital lesions or prodromal symptoms (pain, tingling) are present at labour.
  • Vaginal delivery is allowed if asymptomatic at the time of delivery, despite HSV history.

Breastfeeding: Safe if no active breast lesions are present.

Explanation for other options:

Administer one dose of acyclovir if she has active genital herpes at the time of delivery (Option A). Acyclovir should be given for 7-10 days in case of active herpes infection.

Administer prophylaxis with acyclovir from now until delivery, whether she has active herpes or not (Option B). We have to give acyclovir for 7-10 days, then stop and restart at 36 weeks of gestation.

Perform elective LSCS even if the mother is asymptomatic at the time of delivery. (Option C) Not recommended if there are no active lesions or symptoms.

questions.text: The drug of choice for syphilis in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Penicillin is the drug of choice for syphilis in pregnancy.

Congenital syphilis:

  • Transmission of T. pallidum across the placenta from a syphilitic woman to her fetus may occur at any gestational age.
  • Untreated infection leads to fetal loss in 40% cases, IUD, stillbirth and abortions. Stillbirths are more common than abortions.)

Diagnosis:

  • The presence of anti-treponemal IgM antibodies in neonates is diagnostic of congenital syphilis (IgG antibodies are not specific for neonatal infection and may be the result of transplacental transmission from a mother who has been adequately treated).
  • VDRL and RPR tests are used for rapid screening. A VDRL titre in neonates 4 times greater than the maternal titre is consistent with congenital syphilis.

In Asymptomatic infants:

  • If the mother has been treated with penicillin in the 1st/2nd trimester, no treatment is needed for the infant
  • If the mother has not been treated/received treatment with penicillin in the third trimester, treat the infant with penicillin.

Treatment

  • Syphilis therapy during pregnancy is given to eradicate maternal infection and to prevent congenital syphilis.
  • Parenteral penicillin G remains the preferred treatment for all stages of syphilis during pregnancy.
  • There are no proven alternative therapies for syphilis during pregnancy. Erythromycin may be curative for the mother, but because of limited transplacental passage, it does not prevent all congenital disease.
  • Women with H/O penicillin allergy, first penicillin desensitisation should be done, and then followed by penicillin injection.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in infants is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Perinatal transmission is the most common cause of vertical transmission of HIV infection in infants.

Maternal transmission of HIV to the child:

  • Antepartum (Transplacental)
  • Peripartum (exposure to maternal blood and body fluids at delivery)
  • Postpartum (breastfeeding).

The maximum risk of transmission is in the peripartum period, followed by labour.

  • In the absence of any intervention, an estimated 15-30% of mothers with HIV infection will transmit the infection during pregnancy and delivery, and 10-20% will transmit the infection through breastfeeding.
  • Vertical transmission of HIV-1 occurs mostly during the intrapartum period (50-70%).

Factors Increasing Vertical Transmission of HIV:

Disease-Related Factors:

  • High maternal viral load (most important risk factor)
  • Seroconversion during pregnancy or early HIV infection
  • Advanced maternal disease
  • Low CD4 count (immunosuppression)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Chorioamnionitis

Obstetric Factors:

  • Vaginal delivery
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Preterm delivery
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Coexisting STDs (especially HSV, syphilis)
  • Low birth weight or placental infection
  • Antepartum invasive procedures (e.g., amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling)
  • Intrapartum invasive procedures (e.g., instrumental delivery, episiotomy, fetal scalp electrodes)

choices.text: Despite the potential for fetal infection, she may opt out of the test
Early antiretroviral therapy will decrease the chances of transmitting the infection to the baby.
CDC recommends screening only for patients with high-risk factors
The risk of the test includes the potential for fetal loss.

questions.text: A 19-year-old G2P1 woman at 9 weeks' gestation presents to the obstetrics and gynaecology clinic for her second prenatal visit. She reports no complaints other than occasional nausea. She had her first child by spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications. She is taking no medications and denies ethanol, tobacco, or current drug use. While she does admit to a history of intravenous drug abuse, she denies using them since the birth of her first child. Over the past several months, she has had multiple sexual partners and does not use contraception. On physical examination, she is in no acute distress. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm, with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. She is informed that she will need the routine prenatal tests, including an HIV test. The physician informs her of the risks and benefits of the HIV test. What else should the physician inform the patient about before performing the test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Before performing an HIV test in pregnancy, the physician must inform the patient that she has the right to refuse the test, even though it is highly recommended to protect both maternal and fetal health.

  • The CDC and ACOG (2008) have recommended prenatal screening for HIV using an opt-out approach, which means that the woman is notified that HIV testing is included in a comprehensive set of antenatal tests, but that testing may be declined.
  • Women are given information regarding HIV, but are not required to sign a specific consent form.
  • Screening is performed using an ELISA test, which has a sensitivity of > 99.5%
  • A positive test is confirmed with either a western blot or an immunofluorescence assay (IIFA), both of which have high specificity.
  • According to the CDC, antibodies can be detected in most patients within 1 month of infection, and thus, antibody serotesting may not exclude early infection.

questions.text: Which drug is given to prevent HIV transmission from mother to child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nevirapine is an antiretroviral drug commonly used to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

  • Traditionally, the therapy given to prevent fetomaternal transmission of HIV has been zidovudine.
  • But the cost of the therapy makes it out of reach for many patients in developing countries.
  • One important study in Uganda demonstrated that a single dose of nevirapine given to the mother at the onset of labour, followed by a single dose to the newborn within 72 hours of birth, decreased transmission by 50% compared with a regimen of zidovudine to the mother.
  • The cost of this regimen is much cheaper than that of zidovudine and thus is being used increasingly in developing countries for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission.
  • Zidovudine treatment of HIV infected pregnant women from the beginning of the 2nd trimester through delivery and of the infant for 6 weeks following birth dramatically decreased the rate of intrapartum and perinatal transmission of HIV infection from 22.6% in the untreated group to 5%.

Universal HAART in Pregnancy:

  • All HIV-positive pregnant women should be started on HAART, regardless of CD4 count and viral load
  • HAART involves 3 or more antiretrovirals from at least two classes.
  • If a woman already on HAART becomes pregnant, her treatment is continued throughout pregnancy.
  • HAART can reduce the risk of vertical (mother-to-child) HIV transmission to <2%.

IV Zidovudine is specifically given during labour and delivery to women:

  • With HIV RNA viral load >400 copies/mL, or
  • With an unknown viral load near delivery.

Reference: Nevirapine - StatPearls

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with known HIV infection is 38 weeks pregnant and presents for delivery planning. Her viral load is detectable, and she has been on antiretroviral therapy. The obstetric team is reviewing measures to minimise the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. Which of the following is not recommended as a strategy to reduce vertical transmission of HIV?
questions.solution:
Omitting ergometrine is not recommended as a strategy to reduce vertical transmission of HIV. Ergometrine is given as a uterotonic for PPH prevention; no role in preventing HIV transmission.

For prevention of mother-to-child transmission, the following steps are advocated intrapartum:

  • Nevirapine/zidovudine during labour (most recommended) (Option D):
  • If viral copies are >1000/ml then elective cesarean should be done otherwise vaginal delivery can be attempted. (Option A):
  • Women with HIV infection should be scheduled for induction of labour or cesarean delivery at 38 weeks of gestation. The reason for this timing of delivery is to avoid rupture of membranes before labour.
  • Avoid breastfeeding.
  • If vaginal delivery is being done, ARM during labour is avoided.
  • The newborn of an HIV infected mother is treated with oral zidovudine, 2 mg/kg every 6 hrs for the first 6 weeks of life. (Option C):
  • There is no role of vitamin A supplementation in preventing transmission. It is seen that vitamin A deficiency has been noted in pregnant females with HIV, so vitamin A supplementation is done.

choices.text: Vaccinate infant with OPV and MMR

questions.text: Regarding transmission of HIV to an infant from an infected HIV mother, which statement is false :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Live vaccines (like OPV and MMR) are contraindicated in symptomatic HIV infection or if the infant is immunocompromised.

  • An HIV infected woman on no ART presents in labour, management includes: Starting on zidovudine IV or starting zidovudine plus a single dose of nevirapine. (Option A):
  • If nevirapine is initiated, consider adding lamivudine for 7 days postpartum to decrease nevirapine resistance.
  • Elective cesarean is the best mode of delivery, as the chances of transmission of HIV are less.
  • Breastfeeding should be avoided except in those cases where the mother cannot afford formula feeds. (Option C)
  • Vertical transmission to the neonates is about 14-25%. (Option B):
  • Transmission of HIV-2 is less frequent (1-4%) than for HIV-1 (15-40%)
  • Varicella and MMR are recommended for children in immune categories 1 and 2, but neither varicella nor MMR vaccines should be given to severely immunocompromised children (immune category 3)

questions.text: Large placenta is seen in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A large (placentomegaly) placenta is typically seen in infections or conditions that cause increased placental inflammation or hyperplasia. In IUGR, the placenta is often small or hypoplastic, reflecting poor perfusion or insufficiency.

A large placenta is seen in the case of Hydrops fetalis, which has two variants.

  • Immune hydrops: It is due to Rh isoimmunisation and accounts for 1/3rd of cases of hydrops fetalis
  • Nonimmune hydrops fetalis (NIHF): It is due to conditions other than Rh isoimmunisation and accounts for 2/3 cases of hydrops fetalis

Infections causing NIHF:

  • Of all the PRATSCHEC agents (parvovirus, rubella, AIDS, toxoplasma, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, herpes, echovirus, and coxsackievirus), only AIDS has not been reported in association with Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis.
  • Parvovirus B-19 is the most common viral infection associated with NIFH.

Explanation for other options:

Syphilis (Option B): Syphilitic placentitis can lead to a thickened and enlarged placenta due to villous oedema and inflammation.

CMV (Option C): CMV infection can cause placental enlargement due to chronic villitis and oedema.

Rubella (Option D): Rubella may cause villitis, leading to placental enlargement.

questions.text: Cesarean section is preferred in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cesarean section is preferred in Genital herpes (caused by HSV-2) to reduce the risk of neonatal transmission.

Effects of herpes on pregnancy:

  • If there is a primary infection in the last trimester, there are chances of premature labour or IUGR.
  • Transplacental infection is not usual.
  • The fetus becomes affected by virus shed from t.he cerivx or lower genital tract during vaginal delivery
  • The baby may be infected in utero from the contaminated liquor following rupture of membranes.
  • Risk of fetal infection is high in primary genital HSV at term due to high virus shedding compared to a recurrent infection.
  • Cesarean delivery is indicated in an active primary genital HSV infection where the membranes are intact or recently ruptured and in females with prodromal symptoms of herpes.
  • The drug of choice for genital herpes is acyclovir (when the virus culture is positive).
  • Breastfeeding is allowed provided the mother avoids contact between her lesions, her hands and the baby.
  • Whether there is an increased risk of abortion is still not proven.

Explanation for other options:

Toxoplasmosis (Option A): No need for C-section; transmission is transplacental, not peripartum. Mode of delivery does not significantly affect fetal transmission.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) (Option C): CMV can be transmitted during delivery, but C-section does not prevent this. Infection can occur in utero, intrapartum, or via breast milk.

Varicella Zoster Virus (Option D): Cesarean may be considered only if maternal infection is close to delivery (5 days b, before to 2 days after) to reduce severe neonatal disease and is not routinely indicated.

questions.text: The drug of choice for intermittent preventive therapy during pregnancy in malaria is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MalariaThincludesmittent preventive therapy during pregnancy in malarias include at least two treatment doses of sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine in the second and third trimesters.

  • Intermittent Preventive Therapy is a newer modification of prophylaxis.
  • In chemoprophylaxis, the drugs have to be given daily or weekly, whereas in IPT, the pregnant females are treated for malaria presumptively at fixed times (either twice or thrice) during pregnancy using drugs with a long half-life.
  • The WHO allows for the use of IPT during pregnancy.
  • The Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis during pregnancy is chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine.

Explanation for other options:

Proguanil (Option A): Used for prophylaxis, but not recommended as intermittent therapy during pregnancy

Pyrimethamine-dapsone (Option B): Not used due to higher toxicity and resistance concerns

Quinine (Option D): Used for treatment of malaria in pregnancy, especially in the 1st trimester, not for intermittent preventive therapy

Reference: Sulfadoxine and Pyrimethamine for Intermittent Preventive Treatment of Malaria During Pregnancy and After Delivery

questions.text: Which of the following is a known effect of dengue on fetuses if the mother is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

No evidence of teratogenicity, abortion or IUGR following dengue infection during pregnancy.

Dengue fever in pregnancy

Material risks:

  • Associated with high maternal mortality
  • Deranged liver functions may mimic HELLP syndrome.

Fetal Risks:

  • Vertical transmission is present.
  • The newborn presents with fever, hepatomegaly and thrombocytopenia. In a grave infection, a newborn may show coagulation abnormalities.

questions.text: The drug of choice for pregnant females travelling to areas endemic to chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For pregnant women travelling to areas endemic for chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum, Mefloquine is the drug of choice for malaria chemoprophylaxis.

Mefloquine

  • Safe in 2nd and 3rd trimesters (also used in the 1st trimester if needed)
  • Effective against chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum
  • Given once weekly as prophylaxis
  • Recommended by the CDC and the WHO for pregnant travellers

Explanation for other options:

Primaquine (Option A): Used mainly for hypnozoite eradication (P. vivax, P. ovale), not prophylaxis.

Doxycycline (Option B): Contraindicated in pregnancy due to risk of tooth discolouration, inhibition of bone growth in the fetus

Amodiaquine (Option C): Not preferred for prophylaxis; mainly used for treatment in combination (e.g., with artesunate). Safety in pregnancy is not well established for prophylactic use.

choices.text: Treatment should be started before labour
Avoid mixing of blood intrapartum period
Cesarean section would decrease transmission of HIV to the baby

questions.text: HIV positive primi near term, advice given is all except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an HIV-positive primigravida near term, several precautions and decisions are taken to minimise the risk of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT). So, Vaginal delivery is not preferred in all cases.

HIV

  • Least teratogenic among TORCH infections.
  • Most common time of transmission: Peripartum period (during delivery)
  • Vertical transmission rate: 15-40% (without ART)
  • Risk increased by:
    • High maternal viral load
    • Low CD4 count
    • Vitamin A deficiency
    • Chorioamnionitis

Screening

  • Universal screening during pregnancy.
  • Opt-out strategy (test is done unless the patient declines).
  • Screening test: ELISA, if positive/indeterminate, confirm with Western blot.
  • HIV testing is the first step in PPTCT (Prevention of Parent-To-Child Transmission).

ART Guidelines (WHO 2009 onwards)

  • Start ART in all pregnant women, regardless of CD4 count or viral load.
  • If not already on ART, start from 14 weeks of gestation or as early as possible (even in labour).
  • Avoid Nevirapine in women with CD4 > 250 cells/mm³ (risk of hepatotoxicity).

Infant Prophylaxis

  • Breastfeeding infants: Daily Nevirapine from birth until 6 weeks.
  • Non-breastfeeding infants: Daily Zidovudine or Nevirapine for 6 weeks.
  • Elective Cesarean at 38 weeks if viral load >1000 copies/mL. After ROM, the C-section benefit is lost.
  • Vitamin A supplementation for all HIV+ pregnant women.
  • Nevirapine supplied free by NACO for both mother and baby.
  • With HAART + Zidovudine + Cesarean, MTCT reduced to <2%

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 34 weeks' gestation presents to the labour and delivery floor with the chief complaint of regular contractions, bloody show, and a gush of fluids. A 2.3 kg boy is delivered by spontaneous vaginal delivery without further complication 1 hour after presentation. Twenty-four hours later, the infant has developed irritability, fever, and respiratory distress. He is diagnosed with sepsis secondary to pneumonia. The mother has no complaints other than anxiety regarding the condition of her child. She denies rigours, chills, sweats, nausea, or vomiting. The mother's pulse is 60/min, blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, and temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Physical examination reveals lungs that are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops are present on cardiac examination. The suprapubic region is not tender to palpation. Vaginal and cervical examination reveals no significant tears or bleeds. Which prenatal test would have provided the most useful information in preventing this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The infant presented with symptoms of irritability, fever, and respiratory distress within 24 hours of birth. So the diagnosis is Neonatal sepsis secondary to pneumonia. Most commonly caused by Group B Streptococcus.

So, Rectovaginal group B streptococcal culture would be useful as GBS colonises the maternal genital tract and is transmitted vertically during labour/delivery. GBS screening is done at 35-37 weeks of gestation.

  • Neonatal Sepsis is commonly caused by Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae)
  • The major cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality
  • Clinical Presentation with early-onset sepsis (within 24-48 hours)
    1. Respiratory distress
    2. Apnea
    3. Hypotension
    4. Lethargy, poor feeding
  • Universal rectovaginal culture screening at 35-37 weeks of gestation
  • Swabs collected from lower third of the vagina and rectum
  • GBS colonisation of the birth canal arises from anorectal colonisation
  • If a woman presents in preterm labour (<37 weeks) before GBS screening, or at term with unknown GBS status, intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) should be started immediately with IV Penicillin G
  • Intrapartum Antibiotic Prophylaxis (IAP) prevents vertical transmission during labour and reduces the risk of early-onset neonatal sepsis
  • Cesarean is not indicated for GBS prevention if membranes are intact and labour has not started
  • GBS prophylaxis is needed if:
    • Preterm labor <37 weeks
    • ROM ≥18 hours
    • Maternal fever ≥38°C
    • Previous baby with GBS disease
    • GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy

Explanation for other options:

Cervical Chlamydia culture (Option A): Chlamydia can cause conjunctivitis or pneumonia, but symptoms appear after 1-2 weeks, not within 24 hours.

Cervical gonorrhea culture (Option B): Gonorrhea can cause ophthalmia neonatorum, but rarely causes sepsis or pneumonia.

ELISA for HIV (Option C): Important for long-term infant care, but not associated with early-onset sepsis or pneumonia in neonates.
